questions.question:
Question 1: A 42-year-old male prisoner is being evaluated for aggressive tendencies and antisocial 
behavior. Which of the following genotypes is associated with these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
XYY genotype is often associated with aggressive tendencies, antisocial, and often, criminal 
behavior. It is called Jacob’s syndrome. Option A: XXY genotype is associated with Klinefelter's syndrome. Option B: XO genotype is associated with Turner's syndrome. Option C: Triple X syndrome is associated with genotype XXX. It is also called super female.

questions.question: Question 2: What is the risk of developing Down's syndrome in a baby born to a 45-year-old woman?
questions.explanation:
The risk of developing Down’s syndrome in a baby born to a 45-year-old woman is 1 in 50. The risk of developing of Down's syndrome in a baby born to a 20-year-old woman is around 1 in 
3000 and it increases with rising maternal age. It is an autosomal disorder caused by trisomy of 
chromosome 21. 910

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following conditions is not autosomal dominant?
questions.explanation: Ataxia-telangiectasia or Louis-Bar syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition. Autosomal dominant conditions include: • Neurofibromatosis • Marfan’s syndrome • Retinoblastoma • Huntington's chorea • Polycystic kidney disease

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is incorrect regarding autosomal recessive disorders?

options.a: Both male and female offspring are affected
options.c: Most inborn errors of metabolism have this form of inheritance
options.d: It affects more people at a later age than in childhood

questions.explanation:
Autosomal recessive disorders usually manifest in childhood or earlier. Heterozygotes are unaffected by the disease. When both parents are heterozygous, each offspring 
(both male and female) has a 1:4 chance of being affected. Examples of autosomal recessive 
disorders include several inborn errors of metabolism like phenylketonuria, cystic fibrosis, and 
galactosemia.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 6-year-old boy with recurrent hemarthrosis was found to have deficiency of factor VIII. He 
was adopted and his family history is unknown. What is the inheritance pattern of this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hemophilia A. It is an X-linked recessive disorder. Hemophilia is of two types: • Hemophilia A - due to mutations in the F8 gene leading to factor VIII deficiency • Hemophilia B - due to mutations in the F9 gene leading to factor IX deficiency Affected children often present with prolonged bleeding after procedures like circumcision or 
major bleeds like intracranial hemorrhages. When the child begins to walk, bleeding into the joint 
(hemarthrosis) may occur, causing painful swellings and reddening. Laboratory investigations show elevated aPTT, with normal PT and platelet count. It is treated by 
the administration of factor VIII or factor IX concentrates.

questions.question:
Question 6: A pathologist is examining the peripheral smear of a patient with anemia. Which of the 
following is incorrect about the epidemiology of this disease?

options.a: It is prevalent in areas with high frequency of malaria
options.b: It is an autosomal dominant disorder
options.c: Couples at risk can undergo prenatal testing and diagnosis
options.d: It manifests during the first year of life

questions.explanation:
The given peripheral smear shows sickling of RBCs, suggestive of sickle cell anemia. It is an 
autosomal recessive disorder. The prevalence is high among Africans. This disorder usually has its onset during the first year of 
life. Couples at risk can opt for prenatal testing and diagnosis as well. 911

questions.question: Question 7: What was the primary goal of the Human Genome Project?

options.a: To introduce a gene sequence into a cell
options.b: To develop new diagnostic techniques for genetic disorders
options.c: To determine the sequence of nucleotide base pairs in human DNA
options.d: To study the precise genetic composition of specific populations

questions.explanation:
The primary goal of the Human Genome Project was to determine the sequence of nucleotide base 
pairs that make up human DNA and to map all genes from the human genome (20,500 genes). The project was launched in 1990 and deemed complete in 2003.

questions.question: Question 8: What is Hardy-Weinberg law related to?
questions.explanation:
The Hardy-Weinberg law is related to population genetics. Population genetics is the study of the 
precise genetic composition of a population and various factors determining the incidence of 
inherited traits in them. Founder effect is a violation to this law. It is due to difference in expression of the genes in 
founding population. This is responsible for the difference in the distribution of disease in 
population.

questions.question: Question 9: The Hardy-Weinberg law is applicable in populations with which of the following?
questions.explanation: The Hardy-Weinberg law is applicable for infinitely large, static populations with random mating.

questions.question: Question 10: Match the following.
questions.explanation:
Positive eugenics encourages the breeding of those with desirable phenotypes. Negative eugenics discourages the breeding of those with undesirable phenotypes. Euthenics is the environmental manipulation to enable genes to express themselves. Euphenics is the science of making phenotypic improvements in humans after birth, generally to 
affect a problematic genetic condition.

Sold by @itachibot A young woman with a family history of beta-thalassemia is planning to marry her first 
cousin. Which of the following will you recommend for this woman?
questions.explanation:
This young woman must be advised to undergo prospective counseling. It refers to the process explaining to heterozygous individuals the risk of having affected children 
if they marry another heterozygous individual. It is performed prior to conception. Retrospective counseling is performed after the genetic disorder has already occurred in the first 
child. 912

questions.question:
Question 12: A 40-year-old pregnant woman is planned for amniocentesis. What is the gestational age at 
which it can be done at the earliest?
questions.explanation:
Amniocentesis can be done as early as 14 weeks of gestation. It refers to the examination of a sample of amniotic fluid to diagnose chromosomal disorders and 
some metabolic errors. It is indicated in the following cases: • Pregnant women aged 35 years or above • Family history of: • Chromosomal abnormalities • Metabolic errors • Chromosomal translocation • Sex-linked genetic disease

questions.question: Question 13: What is a Punnett square used for?
questions.explanation:
A Punnett square is a diagram used to predict the probability of a particular genotype in an 
offspring. It is a standard tool for genetic counselors. The image given below shows a Punnett square.

questions.question: Question 14: The risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is?
questions.explanation:
The risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is 4-8%. The risk of genetic diseases in non-consanguineous marriage is 2-4%. 913
